problem:
The number
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ\]is expressed in the form $r \, \text{cis } \theta$, where $r > 0$ and $0^\circ \le \theta < 360^\circ$.  Find $\theta$ in degrees.
solution:
First, we note that the angle measures form an arithmetic sequence whose average is $111^\circ$.

We have that
\begin{align*}
&\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ  \\
&= \frac{\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ}{\text{cis } 111^\circ} \cdot \text{cis } 111^\circ \\
&= [\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)] \text{cis } 111^\circ.
\end{align*}The terms of the sum
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]can be paired into terms of the form $\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ$, and
\begin{align*}
\text{cis } n^\circ + \text{cis } (-n)^\circ &= \cos n^\circ + i \sin n^\circ + \cos n^\circ - i \sin n^\circ \\
&= 2 \cos n^\circ,
\end{align*}which is real.  Therefore,
\[\text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ)\]is real.  Let
\[r = \text{cis } (-36^\circ) + \text{cis } (-28^\circ) + \text{cis } (-20^\circ) + \dots + \text{cis } (36^\circ).\]Then
\[\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 91^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ = r \, \text{cis } 111^\circ,\]so $\theta = \boxed{111^\circ}$.
model_solution:
The given expression can be written as a sum of complex numbers in the form of $e^{i\theta}$ where 
$\text{cis} \  \theta = e^{i \theta}$.

We can start by grouping the terms of the sum into pairs, such that the arguments of the complex numbers in each pair add up to 164 degrees:

\begin{align*}
&\text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 147^\circ \\
+ \,&\text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 139^\circ \\
+ \,&\text{cis } 91^\circ + \text{cis } 133^\circ \\
+ \,&\text{cis } 99^\circ + \text{cis } 127^\circ \\
+ \,&\text{cis } 107^\circ + \text{cis } 121^\circ \\
+ \,&\text{cis } 115^\circ + \text{cis } 115^\circ \\
+ \,&\text{cis } 123^\circ 
\end{align*}

The sum can be written as
\begin{align*}
S & = \text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 147^\circ + \dots + \text{cis } 147^\circ \\
 & = \left( \text{cis } 75^\circ + \text{cis } 147^\circ \right) + \left( \text{cis } 83^\circ + \text{cis } 139^\circ \right) + \left( \text{cis } 91^\circ + \text{cis } 133^\circ \right) + \dots + \text{cis } 123^\circ \\
 & = \left( \text{cis } 111^\circ \right) + \left( \text{cis } 111^\circ \right) + \left( \text{cis } 111^\circ \right) + \left( \text{cis } 111^\circ \right) + \left( \text{cis } 111^\circ \right) + \left( \text{cis } 115^\circ \right) + \left( \text{cis } 123^\circ \right) \\
\end{align*}
Now, 
\begin{align*}
S & = 6 (\text{cis } 111^\circ) + \text{cis } 115^\circ + \text{cis } 123^\circ
\end{align*}

Now, using the property of complex numbers, we can write the sum as 
\begin{align*}
S & = 6 \left(\text{cis } 111^\circ \right) + \text{cis } 115^\circ + \text{cis } 123^\circ \\
 & = 6 \, \text{cis } 111^\circ +  \text{cis } 115^\circ +  \text{cis } 123^\circ \\
 & = 6 \left( \cos 111^\circ +  i\sin 111^\circ \right) + \left( \cos 115^\circ +  i\sin 115^\circ \right) + \left( \cos 123^\circ +  i\sin 123^\circ \right) \\
 & = \left( 6\cos 111^\circ + \cos 115^\circ + \cos 123^\circ \right) +  i \left( 6\sin 111^\circ + \sin 115^\circ + \sin 123^\circ \right) \\
 & = \left( 6\cos 111^\circ + \cos 115^\circ + \cos 123^\circ \right) +  i \left( 6\sin 111^\circ + \sin 115^\circ + \sin 123^\circ \right) \\
 & \approx (2.959 +  0.573 + 0.593) + i(5.237 + 0.319 + 0.802) \\
 & \approx 4.125 + 6.358 i.
\end{align*}
The magnitude of this complex number is 7.1, which is approximately $\sqrt{4.125^2 + 6.358^2}$.  Therefore, the complex number is at an angle of $\tan^{-1} \frac{6.358}{4.125} \approx 55.3^\circ$ above the x-axis.
